column1: For records in the BDRC database, indicate it here (ex: P123), for duplicates, indicate all IDs, for records not in the BDRC database, create an ID starting with P1TMP (ex: P1TMP123)
column2: names_tib
column11: notes

column1: for records in the BDRC database, indicate it here (ex: P123), for duplicates, indicate all IDs, for records not in the BDRC database, create an ID starting with P1TMP (ex: P1TMP123)
column2: coma separated list of names in Tibetan, prefilled witht the primary name in the BDRC database
column3: comma-separated list of Sanskrit names, in IAST. BDRC has very sparse data of this kind and this has been prefilled with some strings from Otani and Tibskrit
column12: write OK if identification+dating is certain; write X if the person is ambiguous and if the data is uncertain; further details should be writted under "notes"
column14: ma = main author, pa = pandita, tr = translator

column11: NB: BUDA: 1002/1012–1097/1100. Ducher, Building a Tradition (2017), p. 302: 1000–1081; 1012–1097; 1024–1107 (she favours the “early tradition”).

column2: lo tsA ba ga rod tshul khrims 'byung gnas/
shes rab brtsegs pa/
column11: RR: 11th c.; Tibskrit 11th c.; BDRC references bio according to which he is contemporaneous w/ mar pa chos kyi dbang phyug, so he may be active in the early 12th c. as well.

column2: lo tsA ba dpal 'byor snying po/
zhang lo tsA ba grub pa dpal/

lo tsA ba 'bro dge bsnyen shes rab brtsn 'grus/

column11: NB: Same as Bal po Ma hā pa na (*Mahāpāna?)? If so, Tibskrit: Newar, Later Spread.

column2: shud ge lo tsA ba grags pa rgyal mtshan/
paN+Di ta rat+na pha la/
column11: RC: unlikely to be P753, i.e. Rin chen bzang po, in my opinion, but there are very few clues about who this is; bka' 'gyur colophones all support the spelling Ratnaphala

column2: tsa mi lo tsA ba smon grub shes rab/
column11: NB: = P5169, see Tibskrit, s.v. Abhayadatta (Mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa): "We may conclude from this that the complete name of Rtsa mi is Rtsa mi Sangs rgyas grags pa smon grub shes rab (note the Mi nyag Smon grub shes rab who worked with Abhayadatta on several translations)." Perhaps he flourished between the 11th and 12th cent., see Dowman, Masters of Mahāmudrā, p. 386: "We can guess that sMon grub shes rab was born about 1060, had visited India before 1090 and lived a long life into the twelfth century. Tsa mi Sangs rgyas grags pa was a well known Sanskritist and a translator of the Kālacakra-tantra; sMon grub shes rab may have been one of his initiatory names."

column2: lo tsA ba dge slong dbyig gi rin chen/
byams gling paN chen bsod nams rnam rgyal/
khrims khang lo tsA ba bsod nams rgya mtsho/
column11: NB: aka Khrus khang lo tsā ba, aka bSod nams rgya mtsho'i sde (Tibskrit)

column2: lo tsA ba 'jam dpal sgeg pa'i rdo rje/
lo tsA ba tshul khrims gzhon nu/
lo tsA ba dbang phyug rgyal mtshan/
column11: NB: According to BUDA, father and teacher of Sho rGyal sras legs pa (P7625), aka Shwa ban rGyal sras legs ldan (1290–1365 [1366 Tibskrit; cf. also van der Kuijp, "Chos 'byung rin po che'i gter mdzod," p. 135: "(?1264-1341)"]). Therefore, he presumably flourished between the 13th and 14th cent. (= Cha gan Dbang phyug rgyal mtshan (fl. ca. 1300)?) He is said to have collaborated with P8245 (Buddhākaravarman, who translated the 'Phags ma sgrol ma'i sgrub thabs [D 3689] together with Chos kyi shes rab [P3890]), but he rather seems to have collaborated with Suvidyākaravarman (probably different from Buddhākaravarman), with whom he translated the Ngan song thams cad yongs su sbyong ba gzi brjid kyi rgyal po brtag pa snang ba'i rgyan [D 2627]. Probably the page dedicated to P8245 on BUDA has to be corrected.

column2: brog mi lo tsA ba jo sras/
gos chos 'grub/
sman lung pa shAkya 'od/
column11: RR: 11th c.

column2: snye thang lo tsA ba blo gros brtan pa/

column11: Probably Indian, not Tibetan. Dates unknown. Associated only with one text; translator not mentioned.

column11: ER: duplicate of P318 ?

column2: gu Na shrI/
column11: RC: Translator of Durjayacandra's pañjikā on Cakrasaṃvara, so he can be no earlier than the mid 11th C.; may be the same as P4CZ15107? although I have no reason to support this apart from the Tibetanised form of the name.

column2: pa tshab lo tsA ba tshul khrims rgyal mtshan/
column11: RC: see Tibskrit

column2: lo tsA ba rab mchog dpal bzang /
gos lo tsA ba gzhon nu dpal/
lo tsA ba khu mdo sde 'bar/
zhu chen gyi lo tsA ba ting 'dzin bzang po/
lo tsA ba lha btsan po mu ne rA dza/
column11: NB: Tibskrit, s.v. Bodhigarbha (Byang chub snying po): "I'm a little puzzled by the identity of Munirāja, although it seems likely he should be a Tibetan member of the royal family who became a monk. It is possible the Indian pundit [i.e. Dīpaṅkaracandra] could be Atiśa, although I imagine it could also be Divyākaracandra."

column2: lo tsA ba shAkya blo gros/
column11: ER: not duplicate of P4CZ16874 according to BDRC librarians

lo tsA ba dpal gyi lhun po/
column11: RR: early 9th c.

column2: mang mkhar lo tsA ba mchog ldan legs pa'i blo gros/
lo tsA ba sna nam rdo rle bla ma/
column11: NB: Disc. of Padmasambhava; Tibskrit, s.v. Lang gro Lo tsā ba Dkon mchog 'byung gnas: "note that Sna nam Rdo rje bdud 'joms is the only other one said to have been a minister of Khri srong lde btsan." Note that the name is wrongly spelled "sna nam rdo *rle*" (instead of rje) in the "names_tib" column and in BUDA.

lha zhi ba 'od/

lo tsA ba ye shes snying po/

column2: sa skya paN+Di ta kun dga' rgyal mtshan/
lo tsA ba bzang skyong /
lo tsA ba khi ne tso/
lo tsA ba bkra shis rgyal mtshan/
lo tsA ba dharma A lo ka
zhe sdang rdo rje/
lo tsA ba mang 'or byang chub shes rab/
lo tsA ba cog gru shes rab bla ma/
sa skya bla chen kun dga' rgyal mtshan/
zhwa lu lo tsA ba chos skyong bzang po/
zhu chen gyi lo tsA ba dga' rdor/
lha rin po che/
column11: RR: 11th-12th c. NB: Martin, Biographical References (Tibetological): Part One (Ming mdzod), no. 1871: b. about late 11th.

column2: lo tsA ba pra dz+nyA sing ha/
column11: RC: BDRC website's 'notes' associate him with Tōh 199 (work translated from Chinese), but Tōh 199 is linked in this spreadsheet with P2139. Old BDRC website associates this person with a translation of a text by Jñānapāda (from Sanskrit), Tōh 3905. This is probably the person in question. BUDA associates him with Tōh 3906, although colophon doesn't attest the involvement of anybody by this name. The latter appears to be some kind of glitch. The translator of Tōh 3905 is mysterious.

column2: gro mgon chos rgyal 'phags pa/
lo tsA ba bsod nams rgyal ba/
column11: RC: P4209 (bsod nams rgyal ba) is given as mid 11th C date in Gangs can mkhas grub. Otherwise obscure. Perhaps he is in fact bsod nams rgyal mtshan, but no further evidence for this.

column2: zha ma lo tsA ba ston pa seng+ge rgyal po/
column11: RC: Certainly active in 12thc, but so far see little evidence for a solid date.

column2: chag lo tsA ba chos rje dpal/
sgra bsgyur gyi lo tsA ba seng+ge rgyal mtshan/
lo tsA ba lo btsun chung /
lo tsA ba pu rangs bsod nams blo gros/
dpyal lo tsA ba kun dga' grags pa/
column11: NB: should he be the Kun dga' grags who translated the Dbu ma la 'jug pa'i 'grel bshad [D 3870] together with the Kashmiri Jayānanda (12th c.) (as stated in P1159), then he may not bear the epithet dPyal. Notice that the Kasmiri Jayānanda (12th c.) is said to be different from the (East) Indian Jayānanda (first half of 13th c.) who translated astrological texts (Svarodaya, etc.) (van der Kuijp 1993: 194–195). Correct texts and floruit of P4CZ15242.

column2: g.yag sde lo tsA ba bsod nams seng+ge
lo tsA ba glan dar ma tshul khrims/
column11: RC: cf. Tibskrit

column2: lo tsA ba tshul khrims yon tan/
lo tsA ba dge slong g.yung drun g'od/
lo tsA ba skyob pa dpal bzang po/
bro lo tsA ba shes rab grags pa/
blo bzang chos grags/
tshul dge rin chen/
rlangs dpal gyi seng+ge
gyi jo zla ba'i 'od zer/
lo tsA ba 'bro seng dkar shAkya 'od/
ba ri lo tsA ba rin chen grags/
rgyal ba'i 'byung gnas/
kam kam lo tsA ba chos kyi ye shes/
lo tsA ba rba ye shes bzang po/
lo tsA ba khu ston dngos grub/
column11: RC: worked with Jñānākara (11th C) on a number of translations (see @wenta2018); worked with Atiśa on Cittaviśuddhiprakaraṇa (P 5208) and D 3778; worked revised by Nag tsho lo tsA ba (1011‑1064), so must be earlier or at the same time; not certain if the translator of the Sūnyatāsaptatī is him or not; may be the same as P3464, who lived at the same time and is said to be a translator, also treated as such in TibSkrit, but rather uncertain—haven't seen an alternative name given for him; Ngag dbang kun dga' bsod nams, in one of his works, refers to "yar lung lo tsA ba khu ston dngos grub 'byung gnas" (folio number unknown); don't see the relationship with the people mentioned in the "worked with" column;

column2: lo tsA ba bsod nams rgyal mtshan/
rngog byang chub 'byung gnas/
gnubs lo tsA ba tshul khrims shes rab/
se lo tsA ba/
lo tsA ba chings yon tan 'bar/
lo tsA ba mkha' 'gro rdo rje/
column11: RC: TibSkrit cites gangs can mkhas grub, p. 214

column2: chos grags/
lo tsA ba khu rnal 'byor/
grags pa byang chub/
column11: NB: floruit 13th c. since he worked with Gautamabhadra (P4CZ15161)

column2: lo tsA ba le'u ston rgya nag
column11: Edited a translation done by Somanātha (11th Kashmiri paṇḍita who executed his own translations). Somanātha arrived in Tibet in 1027 (accord to Tresury of Lives pages on Kālacakra), so le'u ston rgya nag must have been active some time after that.

column2: lo tsA ba phyug brtsams dbang phyug rgya mtsho/
gar lo tsA ba chos kyi bzang po/,mgar chos kyi bzang po/
column11: RC: He is different from P3939 (i.e. dpyal chos kyi bzang po); translated a large number of works by *Jabariba in Nepal with Devapūṛṇamati; quite a few of those works are associated with P3939, which is probably a mistake.

column2: sa lo kun dga' bsod nams/
lo tsA ba phyug 'tshams dbang phyug rgyal po/
myang ting 'dzin bzang po/
zhang mdo sde dpal/
lo tsA ba shAkya bshes gnyen/
phag mo gru pa sde srid 01 byang chub rgyal mtshan/
rong ston shes bya kun rig
khon klu'i dbang po/
column11: disciple of Padmasambhava

column2: rgya mtsho'i sde/
lo tsA ba dge ba dpal/
ra byid lo tsA ba/
rdo rje sems ma/
column11: Paṇḍita who worked with the translator in a charnel ground in Kashmir. Can be given 11th C date if dating for 'gar shes rab 'byung gnas is accurate.

column2: dpal ldan chos skyong /
column11: NB: not enough info to establish who he is. If based only on whom he is said to have worked with, perhaps 700–799.

column2: lo tsA ba phur bu 'od/
column11: RC: BDRC cites ming mdzod as giving 11th C date. Worked with mi myam rdo rje (given as Atayavajra in colophon; probably Atulyavajra). TibSkrit (erroneously?) gives this paṇḍita's name as Amoghavajra (i.e. P8224). mi mnyam rdo rje is likely to be an 11th C student of Maitripāda, hence the dating for this translator.

column2: legs kyi sde/
column11: NB: he appears to have translated only the dGe ba'i rtsa ba yongs su 'dzin pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen po'i mdo [D101] with Prajñāvarman (fl. 800–999).

column2: mchog gi dbang phyug
column11: RC: Not a translator but a paṇḍita. Only worked with Shākya brtson 'grus, whose dates are 11th–12th C according to Tibskrit. The latter is frequently also cited in colophons as working with one Rgyal ba mchog, possibly the same person Mchog gi dbang phyug. There is no BDRC entry for Rgyal ba mchog, and none of his works are linked to Mchog gi dbang phyug

column2: chos kyi dbang phyug grags pa/,nga mar pa chos kyi dbang phyug grags pa/
column11: NB: = Mar pa Chos kyi dbang phyug grags pa who tr. D758 and D434 with Atuladāsavajra/Atulyadāsa, and D470 revised by Karmaśrī and Nyi ma rgyal mtshan?

column2: gar shes rab 'byung gnas/
column11: RC: Tentative dating based on Tibskrit, where a Mgar shes rab rdo rje ismentioned in Mkhas grub rim byon is given a mid 11th C birthdate. If the translator was indeed active in Kashmir as the colophon of his text would have us believe, he probably wasn't active much later than this.

column2: rgyus smon lam grags/
column11: NB: RRaine: 11th–12th cent. Tibskrit: He died in magical combat with Rwa Lo (P3143: 1016–1128/98)

column2: rma dgon gling /
column11: RC: Assumes the same flourit as ye she sde, Danaśīla, and Jinamitra. Described in colophon as 'yi ge pa' (scribe). Perhaps he worked later than these three, but there is no evidence to suggest that. His role in the production of the translation is unclear. Name also found in list of early translators.

column2: sgro lo tsA ba rin chen sde/
column11: NB: probably = 'Bro Rin chen sde (late 8th cent.)

column2: kyu ra lo tsA ba tshul khrims 'od zer/
column11: RC: Appears to have only translated Tōh 681. I can find no further information that what's given in the colophon for this translator and Somaśrībhavya, the paṇḍita with whom he worked.

column2: phyug mtshams dgra bcom/
column11: NB: Tibskrit: "Probably the translator Phyug mtshams Dgra bcom is identical to Phyug mtshams Dbang phyug rgyal po" (P4CZ15304) = Phyug(s) '/mtshams Dbang phyug rgya mtsho (see Tibskrit, s.v. Abhiṣekaratnāloka)? He collaborated with P1359 (fl. 1000–1099).

column2: lo tsA ba rin chen 'tsho/
column11: RC: Translated two sūtras, perhaps one more in a non-sDe dge bKa' 'gyur. Association with Chos nyi tshul khrims probably means he worked in the early period, but evidence is weak.

column2: dge slong bsod nams lhun grub/
mkhan chen seng+ge dpal/
smyo shul lung rtogs bstan pa'i rgyal mtshan/
dgyer sgom chen po gzhon nu grags pa/
lo tsA ba dpal 'byor/
grub pa dpal bzang po/
rong pa shes rab seng+ge
shes rab legs pa/
rag shi tshul khrims 'byung gnas/
column11: possible duplicate : P0RK1418

column2: slob dpon rgyal ba'i sras
column11: RC: Indian. Can't find this number on other sheets, but I see a 'rgyal ba'i sras' mentioned on the bsTan 'gyur page with a 'to check' indicated beside his name. If that's the person in question, the author of D4054 is postulated to be Sthiramati by Sakuma (https://tsukuba.repo.nii.ac.jp/record/54529/files/SP_45-212.pdf) and others. No information is available on the author of D4046. In any case, D4054 must have been composed between 5th–7th C, since Xuansang translated it.

column2: shong lo tsA ba blo gros brtan pa/
column11: Attributions are messed up in our database. From RR and DM, DM: Younger brother of Shong Rdo rje rgyal mtshan, RR: 13th c. DM calls him Shong blo brtan II

column2: shong lo tsA ba rdo rje rgyal mtshan/
column11: dates from Verhagen

column2: a tsar+ya dmar po/
column11: NB: often identified with Guhyaprajña/Prajñāguhya (gSang ba shes rab/Shes rab gsang ba), disciple of Kashmiri Ratnavajra in the early 11th c. (Tibskrit; Ruegg, "Problems in the Transmission of Vajrayāna Buddhism", in McKay 2003, vol. 2, p. 127), and sometimes with Gayadhara.

column2: chos rgyal khri srong lde btsan/
khro phu 'od zer 'byung gnas/
column11: NB: = Khro phu Lo tsā ba Byams pa dpal (1173 1225 or 1236?)?

column2: dgra bcom pa chos skyob/
column11: RC: Indian. Compiler of Udānavarga (Tōh. 4099). Sanskrit name given as Dharmatrāta. Approximately three important such figures are identified by modern scholars. The two most important flourised in the 2nd century and 4th century respectively.

column2: pham mthing pa gcen 'jigs med grags pa/
ra ti gupta/
slob dpon dbang pos byin/
column11: NB: Indian. Tibskrit: "Tāranātha made use of his historical work called Buddhapurāṇa in 1,200 verses.", NB: *Indradatta (dBang po[s] [s]byin)

column2: jam dbyangs kha che paN+Di ta/
sde dge rgyal po bstan pa tshe ring /
brug chen 06 mi pham dbang po/
paN+Di ta rnam par rgyal ba dbang po'i zhabs/
column11: NB: Tibskrit: probably same as *Vijayendrasena (Rnam par rgyal ba'i dbang po'i sde), Szanto, "Antiquarian Enquiries", p. 4, n. 15: a Newar scholar, to whom the Yogāmbarasādhanopāyikā (D 1619) of Amitavajra is attributed in the Tib. translation. Amitavajra could be his initiation name. Szanto 2012: 171: "The text is signed by Amitavajra (less likely: Asitavajra), but the Tibetan attribution is to one *Vijayendrasena. If my observations about the palaeographical features of ms. A are correct, he must have lived earlier than the 11th century, but in any case earlier than the late 11th century (the date of ms. B)."

column2: slob dpon rta mchog zhabs/
column11: RC: Indian. A Mahāsiddha. Not enough evidence to estimate a date.

column2: dpal 'phrog byed bzang po/
slob dpon bde byed bdag po/
column11: RC: Indian. As the author of Tōh 1112, see Schneider2015. Possibly the same author as the Nyāyapraveśa (Tōh 4208), attributed in the Tibetan tradition to Dignāga. On this text see Tachikawa1971. Said (according to TibSkrit in a colophon) to be the brother of mTho btsun grub rje (P4CZ10507).

column2: lha bla ma byang chub 'od/
rig pa'i khu byug che ba/
column11: According to the colophon of Peking no. 4872, he is the translator of this work by Dad byed go cha rin chen (probably Śraddhākaravarman). BDRC Dpe bsdur ma page mistakenly gives author as Vibhūticandra. No clear indication of a 'che ba' in the translator's name. The biographical works linked to this person are about an Indian paṇḍita who is not described as coming to Tibet or translating anything. Perhaps the colophon is corrupt and originally said that the text was translated by Śraddhākaravarman and Rin chen bzang po, and that Rig pa'i khu byug is the author. I have no proof of this. As it stands, this person is a complete mystery.

column2: ras chung rdo rje grags pa/
lo tsA ba blo gros dpal bzang /
mkhas grub khyung po rnal 'byor/
sprul sku dga' rab rdo rje/
column11: RC: 'Indian'. I think this figure can be regarded as semi-historical, authorship attributions tentative

column2: ngan lam rgyal ba mchog dbyangs/
column11: NB: One of 25 disc. of Padma; first ordained monk.

column2: lo chen skyabs mchog dpal/
paN+Di ta 'phra ras/
column11: NB: BUDA: = Phra la ring ba. Almogi 1997: 80, n. 228: Phra la ring mo/'Phra la ras. Tibskrit: "In list of Later Spread (Phyi dar) period pundits in Tibet contained in Zhu chen, Bstan 'gyur dkar chag, p. 161, line 8." "According to Mtshan tho, he was in Tibet in the 10th century. It is said that he did grong 'jug on a corpse of a boy in Gtsang rong, and became the Rdzogs chen pa Rong pa Chos bzang (i.e., Rong zom pa)."

column2: slob dpon byams pa mgon/
lo tsA ba ldi ri chos grags/
slob dpon 'gar pa ri pa/
column11: RC: Indian. Wrote on the Hevajratantra, so post 10th C.

column2: sing ga la pa chos kyi nyin byed/
pad+ma 'i thod phreng /
column11: RC: Indian? Given as paṇḍita of Peking 4716, bDud rtsi thigs pa; authorship of this work attributred to 'mtsho skyes rdo rje'. Translator is Jñānakumāra, hence probably not the Saroruhavajra who wrote works on the Hevajratantra. I suspect both author and translator are supposed to be Padmasambhava. TibSkrit says this is a work on the Nāmasaṅgīti, cites an anecdote in Sapaṇ's sDom gsum (Rhoton 2002: 206). But this anecdote is clearly referring to the Amṛtakaṇikā by Raviśrījñāna. Peking 4716 doesn't appear to have anything to do with Nāmasaṅgīti. It appears to begin a section of the bsTan 'gyur with works on the rNying ma tantras. Paṇḍita attribution not found in 5th Dalai Lama's catalogue. See email from Orna for more details

column2: dpa' bo 'od gsal/
column11: NB: Tibetan Histories: circa 1100? Tibskrit: "Kapstein in Linrothe, Holy Madness, pp. 52 53. Two generations intervened between him and Abhayadattaśrī."

column2: rgwa lo gzhon nu dpal/
btsun pa ston gzhon/
mkhan po shes rab thar pa/
column11: RC: Floruit is pinned to Tshul khrims rgyal ba. Wrote and helped translate a commentary on a text by Atiśa. Otherwise there doesn't appear to be much info on him.

column2: sgra tshad pa rin chen rnam rgyal/
yar klung pa seng+ge rgyal mtshan/
slob dpon nyi ma'i seng+ge'i 'od/
column11: NB: van Schaik, "The Sweet Sage and the Four Yogas", p. 61: "9th c.?"

column2: rje btsun kun dga' grol mchog
zhu chen tshul khrims rin chen/
karma lo tsA ba rin chen bkra shis/
ye shes snying po/
lo tsA ba lce khyi 'brug
column11: RC: Author of some grammatical works and apparently also a translator

column2: da rI da pa bsod nams rgya mtsho
column11: NB: BUDA: student of sTag rtse sku skye Mi pham phun tshogs shes rab (1654–1715), whose dates are taken from Ehrhard & Sernesi, "Apropos a Recent Collection of Tibetan Xylographs from the 15th to the 17th Centuries", p. 134.

column2: sa bzang ma ti paN chen blo gros rgyal mtshan/
thang sde snod gsum pa/
column11: ER: Chinese

column2: rong gling lo tsA ba rdo rje dbang phyug
column11: RC: Student of Abhayākaragupta, lived in 11th century according to mtshan mtho

column2: slob dpon byang chub rdo rje/
column11: NB: author of D 1463?

column2: ma ga d+ha'i yul du byung ba'i dge bsnyen nyi ma/
column11: RC: Indian. Wrote a Praise of Vanaratna, which Vanaratna himself helped translate into Tibetan. No known other works. So the person can be assigned flourit based on the dates of Vanaratna. Blue Annels refers to a 'mi'i nyi ma' who praised Vanaratna, apparently from Koliṅga. Maybe these people are the same.

column2: rab 'byor zla ba/
column11: NB: dates given in deokar2014: 60. van der Kuijp, "On the Vicissitudes of Subhūticandra’s Kāmadhenu Commentary on the Amarakoṣa in Tibet": ca. 1050–ca. 1110.

column2: shes rab bsod nams/
column11: RC: Translator of a single sādhana; early 12th century birth date given in Gangs can mkhas grub

column2: rma dge ba'i blo gros
bsod nams mos pa
column11: RC: Can find hardly any information on this person or his collaborator. He worked as a revisor on two early translation. He too, therefore, could be from the early period, but I see no evidence to confirm this.

column2: btsun pa rgya mtsho
column11: NB: Tibskrit: revised D 2727, tr. by Vanaratna and Chos 'khor lo tsā ba, attr. to Padmasambhava. No other info.

column2: zhu chen gyi lo tsA ba ban+de rnam par mi rtog pa
rngog lo chung legs pa'i shes rab
chos smra ba bstan pa'i nyin byed
rnal 'byor rgyud la mkhas pa zha lu pa ye shes rgya mtsho
column11: Tibskrit: revised D 482, tr. by Rin chen bzang po or Rma Dge blo (Dge ba'i blo gros).

column2: lo tsA ba dge tshul nam mkha' rdo rje
pu hrangs lo tsA ba
column11: P0RK500 is possibly a duplicate?

column2: she'u badzra de ba
bod kyi lo tsA ba klan chung
